pros: A budget-priced sound mixer with eight mono inputs
cons: Requires a 9V battery or 9V adapter to run

customer_reviews.title: Very handy little mixer.
customer_reviews.text: This unit is working very well for my small mixing jobs. Simple, direct, easy to use. I run several pickup equipped guitar/mandolins through it to a single amp. This works very well for that purpose. Will be trying it while recording with microphones into my little Sony digital recorder Still learning ways to use it but very happy so far. I love having a battery on board, one less thing to plug in and very good when I'm using a battery powered amp with no wall power nearby. Physically this mixer is pretty small. Very portable.
customer_reviews.author: Brian Thompson

customer_reviews.title: This is a well built little mixer. I am ...
customer_reviews.text: This is a well built little mixer. I am using it with a few battery powered synths and a portable speaker I am thrilled with the performance and the build quality is outstanding.
customer_reviews.author: S. Westcott

customer_reviews.title: I enjoy the fact that I can run it from a ...
customer_reviews.text: I'm really digging this little mixer. I enjoy the fact that I can run it from a 9V battery. I'm using it with my Korg Volcas and it works great. Since my whole setup runs on batteries it makes it very easy to go mobile. Well worth the price.
customer_reviews.author: Joe K.

customer_reviews.title: Really nice mixer for the price
customer_reviews.text: Really nice mixer for the price. Need to use a DC adapter to avoid noise which gets worse as the battery gets drained but this is very common for audio mixers. For the price you can't really beat it. I bought a universal DC adapter to power it and it's been working great for over a year.
customer_reviews.author: Charles Leone

customer_reviews.title: Unit works great with a lot of Flexibility
customer_reviews.text: This is the second unit I have bought. I use it to play audio from my laptop, desktop, MP3 Player and Alexa without switching. I can adjust the levels of each audio source separately. On the other unit, I have the audio from ham radios and since it is mono, I can mix up to 8 radios into one speaker system. The only improvement would be to offer a model with miniature 3.5mm jacks instead of the 1/4" jacks. This would save having to buy adaptors to go from the 3.5 mm to the 1/4"
customer_reviews.author: Ed Allison

customer_reviews.title: It works, but seems to have noise issues
customer_reviews.text: I use this to mix audio outputs from various sources, computers, TV, etc. to a headphone output. With a single input, it sounds just okay. I notices some very faint "chirps", but it's tolerable. However, when I add another input the chirping is amplified considerably. Additionally, when I use the 9V adapter, I notice an additional high pitched ringing noise. The problem may be less noticeable when using speakers, but I would advise you spend a bit extra for a nicer mixer.
customer_reviews.author: John Allen

customer_reviews.title: Great product for budget producers.
customer_reviews.text: This is perfect for what I needed. I have a mini amateur recording studio set up and wanted a way to route all of my hardware into my interface without constantly unplugging cables - this fit the bill so well. Works great right out of the box with my KORG volca series and my Teenage Engineering PO and OP1. Very quiet and super rad. Would recommend to anyone in a similar situation.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: I JUST FELT LOVE WITH IT :)

customer_reviews.title: nice unit

customer_reviews.author: Philip K. Jones

customer_reviews.title: Easy, affordable channel/track extension
customer_reviews.text: Very affordable sub mixer. Can use it to send two mono tracks to two channels or four stereo tracks to four channels. Simple controls, no frills. If all you need it to fit more sources into fewer channels and don't want to spend a whole lot, this is a fantastic solution. I ran out of channels on my main mixer, so I'm sending cymbals/overheads to one channel together and toms to one channel together. Now everything's running back to the live mix and I still have individual volume control of each instrument/mic.
customer_reviews.author: Brent Williams

customer_reviews.title: You Get What You Pay For
customer_reviews.text: You get what you pay for, which in this case, is a very high level of noise and utter lack of electrical isolation. When I touch the chassis there's a nice hum (on battery power at least; it doesn't accept the industry standard 2.1mm barrel plug, and I don't have a 2.5mm plug for the power spec). But hell, it was $25, it's tiny enough for my purposes, and I guess I don't need a high SNR for the particular application.
customer_reviews.author: B

customer_reviews.title: Probably will fit my needs
customer_reviews.text: This will probably fit my needs but the "Owners Manual" leaves a lot to be desired. It only describes the features, no explanation on how to use it, how to connect it, or how to troubleshoot problems. Without a detailed manual, only 3 stars.

customer_reviews.title: Awesome value for the price

The other 4 (left side of stereo?) don't work as well but basically happy. Very happy about what they cram into this little unit. Knob controls alone are worth more than I paid.

I paired it with a Behringer HA400 for my microphone inputs on all the same devices. Now I have a single headphone and mic for everything. Works fantastic for my needs.

customer_reviews.title: I called Nady support and they were happy to replace it

If it came with a power adapter, I would give it 5 stars. Don't count on the battery lasting too long. I called Nady support and they were happy to replace it, if I sent the unit in with a receipt but did not mention that low battery could cause this problem, even when I asked. Needless to say, I will not be replacing it (yet).

product_meta.title: Nady MM-242 4 Stereo / 8 Mono Channel Mini Mixer with mono/stereo mode, ¼” Inputs and outputs – battery powered, or use optional AC adapter
product_meta.description:
Dozens of applications for this extremely useful mixer at a very affordable price 

The Nady MM-242 allows you to easily combine mono or stereo signals together and adjust their relative volumes. Ideal for DJ equipment, synths and guitar rigs, studio, stage, the MM-242 is a great tool to have around everywhere. Mono/stereo mode selector switch determines whether all 8 inputs are mixed to both 1/4" outputs or are preserved as stereo signals, so you have greater flexibility and mixing options. Connect the ¼” outputs of this little workhorse directly to your PA or recording device for ultra-clean audio. Eliminate the need for bulkier, more expensive mixers, and take the MM-242 anywhere with you with its 9VDC operation using either a 9V alkaline battery or the optional PAD-1 AC/DC external adapter. 

Specifications

Input Impedance: 50kΩ
Output Impedance: 120Ω
Maximum Output: +7dBm
Frequency Response: 20Hz-30kHz
THD: 0.07%
S/N: -95dB
Noise Floor: 120uV
Inputs/Outputs: 1/4” unbalanced
Peak LEDs: light 3dB before clipping
Current Drain: 19mA
9V Battery Life: up to 35 hours
Power Requirements: 9V battery or optional PAD-1 AC/DC adapter
feature_bullets: Eight mono ¼” inputs with individual volume control and two ¼” outputs with Master Volume Controls.

Two modes of operation: In stereo mode, 4 inputs (A1 through A4) are routed to output A, while the other 4 inputs (B1 through B4) are routed to output B. In mono mode, all 8 inputs are summed to both outputs, still with separate master volume control
Heavy-Duty Steel Construction with smooth-turn, ultra-stable pots and high-quality jacks. Compact design is easily portable with 9V battery operation
Up to 25dB of gain and professional audio quality: S/N ratio of 95dB and frequency response from 20Hz to 30kHz. Peak LEDs facilitate proper gain adjustment
9VDC powered with either 9V alkaline battery or optional PAD-1 AC/DC external adapter
